title: The Young Unicorns
text:
The Young Unicorns (1968), ) is the title of a <a href="Young%20adult%20literature">young adult</a> suspense novel by <a href="Madeleine%20L%27Engle">Madeleine L'Engle</a>. It is the third novel about the <a href="Madeleine%20L%27Engle%23Chronos">Austin family</a>, taking place between the events of "<a href="The%20Moon%20by%20Night">The Moon by Night</a>" (<a href="1963%20in%20literature">1963</a>) and "<a href="A%20Ring%20of%20Endless%20Light">A Ring of Endless Light</a>" (1980). Unlike those two novels and "<a href="Meet%20the%20Austins">Meet the Austins</a>" (1960), it does not center on <a href="Vicky%20Austin">Vicky Austin</a> specifically, but on a family friend, Josiah "Dave" Davidson.
Plot summary.
As the story opens, the Austin family has settled in a <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> apartment after the events of "The Moon by Night", and made some friends; blind young pianist Emily Gregory and Josiah "Dave" Davidson, who helps Emily get around. Emily is studying under the tutelage of the passionate, leonine Emmanuel Theotocopulous, better known as Mr. Theo. <a href="Canon%20Tallis">Canon Tallis</a>, newly arrived at the <a href="Cathedral%20of%20Saint%20John%20the%20Divine%2C%20New%20York">Cathedral of Saint John the Divine</a> after the events of "<a href="The%20Arm%20of%20the%20Starfish">The Arm of the Starfish</a>", meets the Austin children and their friends just as they encounter an anachronistic <a href="Genie">Genie</a> in a junk shop. Tallis advises and helps to protect the children as they are drawn into a mystery involving the Genie, a street gang called the Alphabats, and the local <a href="bishop">bishop</a>'s strange behavior.
Dave is skeptical of the Genie, as is Suzy Austin, but the others are not sure. Centralized, single-minded activity on the part of the criminal Alphabats excites the suspicion of Canon Tallis, who interrogates Dave and Dr. Wallace Austin. Dr. Austin has been working on the creation and perfection of a <a href="laser">laser</a>-based Micro-Ray, which is so unerringly precise that it may do more than simply penetrate the corporeal. Dave was once a member of the Alphabats, but has turned from their ways. He is in denial of his past, not even talking about it. Tension builds as the 'Bats try to draw Dave into their new mischief, whose mastermind is none other than the Bishop himself. The Genie appears to be the bishop's servant, and also appears to possess a Micro-Ray.
It is revealed that the bishop has given up <a href="hope">hope</a> for the world; that he hopes to establish a state of control over <a href="World%20population">humanity</a>, whereby he may prevent anything he deems detrimental to its success. His Genie, <a href="Utopia%20%28book%29">Hythloday</a>, uses the Micro-Ray to control the Alphabats. A concentrated beam from it stimulates the <a href="brain">brain</a>'s <a href="pleasure">pleasure</a> center, giving the victim a feeling of flight. The Alphabats, hoping to receive more of this pleasure as a reward, carry out the bishop's demands.
Eventually, Rob Austin is captured. Vicky and Emily track him to the Cathedral, where they are joined by Vicky's family, Canon Tallis, and Mr. Theotocopulous. The united group expose the bishop as an imposter, being the original bishop's brother, actor Henry Grandcourt; break apart his plans to seize power; and unmask Hythloday as the dishonest scientist Dr. Hyde. The Micro-Ray is seized. Dave makes his <a href="peace">peace</a> with both his past and future, coming eventually to look upon those who have been with him as his family.
Locations and sources.
The primary setting of the book is the <a href="Cathedral%20of%20St.%20John%20the%20Divine">Cathedral of St. John the Divine</a>, an <a href="Episcopal%20Church%20in%20the%20United%20States%20of%20America">Episcopal</a> <a href="cathedral">cathedral</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. Madeleine L'Engle was a volunteer librarian and writer-in-residence at this cathedral for several decades. It was early in this period in which she wrote "The Young Unicorns". The Austin children and Emily attend school at St. Andrew's School, an Episcopal school that may be based on <a href="St.%20Hilda%27s%20and%20St.%20Hugh%27s%20Anglican%20School">St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's Anglican School</a> where L'Engle taught in the early 1960s. As L'Engle's own family, the Franklins, did in 1959, the Austins at the time of the novel have recently moved back to New York after years of living in rural <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>. Unlike the Franklins, however, who stayed primarily in New York thereafter but also retained their Connecticut farmhouse, the Austins' move to New York is temporary.
Reception.
At the time of the book's publication, "<a href="Kirkus%20Reviews">Kirkus Reviews</a>" said, "The Young Unicorns is a kind of <a href="aggiornamento">aggiornamento</a> of the Austin series and <a href="The%20Arm%20of%20the%20Starfish">The Arm of the Starfish</a>--via cross-references and a congeries of characters--and <a href="A%20Wrinkle%20in%20Time">Wrinkle</a>...the latter because seven-year-old Rob Austin speaks with the same precocious wisdom as <a href="Charles%20Wallace%20Murry">Charles Wallace</a> and, in the clinch, withstands evil with the same indomitable innocence: the roles are interchangeable... Miss L'Engle envelops these melodramatics in church music and theological speculations; she also writes with an insinuating slickness: the insupportable is readable." Writing for "<a href="Analog%20Science%20Fiction/Science%20Fact">Analog Science Fiction/Science Fact</a>", <a href="P.%20Schuyler%20Miller">P. Schuyler Miller</a> said, "There's a distinct flavor of <a href="C.%20S.%20Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a> and <a href="Charles%20Williams%20%28British%20writer%29">Charles Williams</a> to the religious side of the story. The young people are real, the plot is good, the neighborhood comes to life—in short, here is a book by an extremely capable writer which is almost science fiction." In a 2012 essay for <a href="Tor.com">Tor.com</a>, American author and critic <a href="Mari%20Ness">Mari Ness</a> commented, "L'Engle's plotting is tighter here than usual... And if some of the themes of this book, her saddened observation of a rising tide of violence and hatred in the 20th century, her focus on the ability to choose between love and hate—have made regular appearances in previous L'Engle books, and will appear again, here they are woven together in a relatively engaging plot."
Series notes.
"The Young Unicorns" is unusual among the Austin family series of books in that it is written from a <a href="Third-person%20narrative">third-person</a> omniscient <a href="Point%20of%20view%20%28literature%29">point of view</a> and does not have Vicky Austin as its central character. Vicky is the first person <a href="protagonist">protagonist</a> and narrator of the first two novels in the series, "<a href="Meet%20the%20Austins">Meet the Austins</a>" and "<a href="The%20Moon%20by%20Night">The Moon by Night</a>", and of the book that follows "The Young Unicorns", "<a href="A%20Ring%20of%20Endless%20Light">A Ring of Endless Light</a>". "The Young Unicorns" centers largely on the Austins' new friend Dave Davidson, but also has moments from the point of view of each of the Austins (both children and adults) and of Canon Tallis. It takes place approximately six months after "The Moon by Night"; "A Ring of Endless Light" takes place the following summer.
